reviews.review_msg: Dan is arguably one of the worst profs at SFU. His assignments are unclear and have no description or rubric, and when you ask questions he tells you to "read between the lines" which is impossible with his scrambled brain so you just lose marks. Lectures are boring so he makes attendance mandatory and curved down marks by >10% per student. AVOID!!

Marking criteria one of the poorest I have come across in any courses I've encountered so far. It is a writing course, but the corrections and comments are riddled with errors themselves. The rubric for grading had been consistently unclear throughout the course.

Awful lectures that have 0 relation to assignments. The worst part of this class was that he is deliberately uses confusing and vague wording for assignments, leaving you to literally guess what you have to do in order to satisfy his requirements that he pulls out of his ass. Then he docks you marks for not reading his mind. Unbelievably terrible.

Class has a pretty small workload, and that's about the only positive. No criteria for anything and Dan doesn't give clear answers so it's up to you to decipher what you need. He will dock marks for things he said you didn't need for seemingly no reason, and grades are mostly assigned at random because TAs don't know what's going on either. Avoid.

There is no grading criteria, you're basically just told to do things. The TA's seem to pull grades out of thin air. Milan has also not shown up to lectures a few times with no prior announcement. I get that life happens, but profs should still be respectful of students' time. Also, we received all of our grades at the end of the semester.

Worst CMPT prof that I've had to date. Tons of micro assignments with vague requirements and very little guidance, grading is inconsistent and the average is usually very low. The prof is not helpful when asked and would give confusing answers. Grades would take forever to return. Do not take at all cost, waste of time and money.

It's better to take a semester off rather than taking this or any class with him. It's a total waste of the precious money. In zoom sessions he just reads the questions posted in the chat and doesn't teach anything coz he actually has nothing prepared for the course. He is putting students future at stake by giving false marks in major assessments.

WORST PROFESSOR I HAVE EVER HAD Midterm essay grades didn't come out until the very END of the semester&had a 50% average for the whole class. Don't take this class unless you have to, you learn NOTHING. Unclear instructions and a lazy marker as well. The conclusion was worth more than the rest of the paper entirely. Save your money, worst prof.

Lectures are only for questions regarding assignments as many would be too ambiguous otherwise. Encourages appealing grades and there being multiple approaches to writing, but grading is done without much commenting and it is infuriatingly slow (only started grading at end of term). Overall very lazy professor that only pretends to teach.

Lectures are basically Q&A sessions. Most assignments are marked for completion while some are marked harshly for writing style (after receiving no feedback to improve your writing style). He is kind but the course is not useful and marking is haphazardly done. Final project was released late.

Journal entries assigned 3 times per week but I doubt they are even read; do them and get 100%. Quizzes and midterm were most useful content of the course. Almost no lecture content (the course is a waste of time). Group projects are easy if uninspiring.

Makes you read a variety of topics, most of which are CS related. His lectures are quick and not informative. Gives random assignments as he pleases instead of following syllabus. He is kind and approachable but just cant teach well. Doesnt give good feedback on assignments and gives vague requirements. Quizzes have questions not from the lectures.

Extremely lazy, assignments are vague with no criteria and no feedback after. He says all the lack of criteria is "by design" which is fine if we actually got feedback after instead of just a grade. Everything he has taught is stuff you learn from any 1st year first year writing course. I don't know what these reviews are saying but he doesn't care

He is one of a few professors that I have met that actually cares about and listens to the students. There is not much traditional teaching in this course and we need to do most of the work on our own, but the prof is quite accessable and helpful.

He would be a rare prof who genuinely cares for students and eagers to make students think and learn from a communication course. He is a very inspirational and sweet person. It was quite an impressive learning experience. He needs to improve on organizing assignments, sometimes his flexibility works for students, though.

He is a very understand instructor who tries his best to explain difficult concepts to students. Really passionate about what he teaches and it shows. He made his lectures interesting and is always available to lend a helping hand. Great instructor, great person.
Lectures were more like a conversational meetup, we would talk about technical writing and do rewrites together in class. Assignments and Midterms were easy, only thing is that he is sometimes vague.

Milan grew on me a lot as the semester went on. I didn't agree with everything he said, but that wasn't the point. The point was to get you to think critically while writing. Milan cares about your learning. He's very generous giving marks back if you explain your reasoning. There are a lot of small, mundane assignments, but you can do them quickly

For 376W, he really wasn't that hard of a marker. I found the peer marking in the course to be way harsher (probably to torpedo your competitor's marks). His notes are pretty lacking, unless you know what the material is about, its pretty much encrypted text. If you've taken an English class before, you'll do just fine even if you skip every class.

This is a required class that nobody wants to teach - its not that Milan is bad. Lectures are a waste of time. There is lots of assignments but most of them are only worth a few percent. This is a good course to take if you don't want to go to class. Once you get to know him, he is approachable.

I think Milan had his own way of teaching the course. He was very funny sometimes. I felt I learnt a lot to improve my writing skills. My first language is not English btw. If you schedule your time wisely, you won't suffer from this course,tbh. As a third year CS student, you should be able to handle it.

Many assignments. Assignments are "Google it yourself". Criteria for everything (journals, midterm, reports, in-class exercises) unclear. Rubric given after being graded. Deadlines keep getting postponed (midterm was postponed twice on the day before). Monotonous voice (want to sleep? go to class). CS analogies to writing ok. Avoid. Avoid. Avoid.

Milan is way too strict of a marker. He wants us to be clear in our writing, but he does not make his notes, or his assignment criteria clear at all. His exams are ridiculously stupid and the questions are really bad. This class should be easy, but the professor does not clearly explain how he wants us to write.
avoid him.

I think his classes are a good preparation for life outside of academia. Other people mention that his grading criteria is unclear, but so is real life. Treat his lectures as stories from your wise grandpa and you'll learn a lot.

DO NOT take this course with this guy. He does not have a clear criteria in any of his course material and always rambling about irrelevant stuff in lecture which is confusing. Assignment are ambiguous since he does not provide any sort of marking rubric until AFTER we got the grade. Exams are brutally marked and expected 100% error free
Worst presentation skills I have seen at SFU. Doesn't have consistent criteria, and doesn't seem to understand how to teach.
Milan has is own way of approaching the course. A very inspirational way of teaching a class that is meant to be boring. Assignments were not boring at all.
Although the prof may ramble a bit, I've still learned some tips in improving my writing. Midterms and tests were marked pretty hard, but assignments were fairly marked. Overall not a bad prof
Never take this course with this professor. He doesnt know how to teach students and he doesnt have clear idea what he is saying
don't know much about the lesson he is teaching. arrogantly oppose textbook with no convincing reasons.

Milan's lectures were essentially drawn out ramble sessions with the occasional mention of technical writing. I received high grades on all assignments submitted until the last week of the semester where Milan overhauled the grading criteria (without notice) with the seemingly casual decision to begin marking strictly. I got nothing from this class

Milan is the most humble and unique professor I have ever met. This is a man who  inspires students to think for themselves, rather than force them to conform to the set of criteria our education system has created. "Its the teachers fault. If you don't understand the content, you're not a bad student. It's my fault for not explaining it clearly."

He's not a bad prof by any means, but you can tell he's not very passionate about this subject. To be honest, nobody is since this is class is super useless. However, hs assignments and exams and really easy so if you want a stress-free course, this is the one to take.
Barely ever shows up to class. Gets mad at students for asking questions. Instructions are useless and he refuses to clarify. 0/5
The worst prof I have ever had hands down. Avoid at all costs because you will not learn anything. Spend your money on a prof that you will actually learn from and wont have waste your time.

Where to start? Nelsen is horrible in every way possible. She treats university students like high school kids, routinely yelling at people in class because they were 5 minutes late. Throws tantrums. Docks marks unnecessarily. Changed assignment requirements after due dates. Overreaches while she is a lousy teacher unqualified for her position.

This has nothing to do with writing skills. It's mostly on social issues related to female inequality in stem. My female friend went to her office hours, and Nelsen told her not to worry about her grade, as she gives A's to female students.
Nelsen has no idea in computer sciences. Also her grammar is bad, and she makes A LOT of spelling mistakes.

- Mandatory lectures 
- High work load 
- Two 48 hour essays over the weekend 
- A ton of quizzes at the beginning of the semester
- Nothing is related to technical writing 
- Feels like an English and Social Justice bootcamp 
- Everything is micromanaged 
- Changes grading criteria after assignments are due 
- Constantly contradicts herself
AVOID
Jacquie is one of the worst profs at SFU. She isn't qualified to teach CMPT courses, especially upper-div ones.
This course with Nelsen is basically Social Justice Warrior boot camp masquerading as Technical Writing
Course content is does nothing to prepare you for actual technical writing. Feels like I am redoing Grade 11 English.
All of the aforementioned 1 star reviews are accurate.

She doesn't understand her own material, frequently gives contradicting instructions, most of the assignments are redundant. The final paper for this class was split into 3 parts except every part was essentially the same thing.

This might be the worst class I've ever taken, and that's saying a lot. Every singly assignment is completely micromanaged with 3 page tables that detail everything there could possibly be. 
Instructions are inconsistent. 
Lectures are incredibly boring. 
Sometimes has mandatory in-class activities so you still have to show up.

Thanks to her, this course takes up double time than an usual CS course does. I have to say that every single day for a third year CS student is important. But she is able to waste your valuable time on those numerous and useless quizs and assignment. Should she make none decisions that make you happy, don't be suprise because this is typically her

To conclude, this course by Nelsen is heavy-loaded. You will not only expect 80-100 small quizzes and assignments but also two intensive 48-hour projects, which stress you out. (And also an individual essay) Very very limited knowledge you can gain from this course.I won't expect any potential SDE would want to spend such an amount of time on this.

Too many boring quizzes. I guess they are only 5% in the final grade. I ever spent more than 6 hours working on 14 quizzes on weekends. Too many group assignments and individual assignments, asking about teamwork again and over again. It's definitely the worst professor I met at SFU.

Dr. Nelsen really cares about her students and puts lots of effort into making lectures as engaging as possible (many in-class activities). She is very open to feedback about the course and communicates frequently to make sure everyone is kept up to date. There are many assignments (do not take very long), but she marks fairly and quickly.

Professor Nelsen is really nice and genuinely cares about her students, she is very approachable. However, I hate her teaching. Quizzes sucked, no feedback was given and I was unsure what they wanted. Rubrics were very vague and left many of us unsure of what to do for assignments. Comments were only occasionally left on graded material.
Need to pay a lot of effort for a high score, but once you paid, then can receive an ideal grade.
She is ok... She is one of the few instructors who really care about the students.
Worst prof ever... Useless course.

Unlike other classes that make you buy a textbook, this class forces you to buy legos. At least smashing your head with a textbook would give you a concussion that would hopefully let you forget about the terrible experiences of this class...

Dr. Nelsen knows her stuff. Yes, this is a CMPT course, but it is primarily a writing and research course. Dr. Nelsen makes use of Canvas liberally and adds many assignments and quizzes. Most are quick to do, so don't be put off by this. Do the library quizzes right away and make use of what you learn, like Zotero for references; a real time saver!

The workload is ridiculously heavy and completely irrelevant to technical writing in CS. Take this class with Pearce/Milan for a higher grade and 10x less work. She also gets very defensive anytime someone brings up a concern or suggestion. She improved slightly throughout the semester, but still wasn't great.

- Says she would check zoom logs for attendance, but does not - Says she would check canvas logs to prevent cheating during tests, but does not - Loo-ng and typo-filled requirements for assignments - Spams your email (sometimes multiple times for one thing) throughout the term - Terrible workload that surpasses most if not all of my CMPT courses.

Yes, this course can be disorganized and a lot of her content looks copied from 105. Yes, you will do the work of two classes. Yes, this class did not closely follow the outline for the course. However, it's not difficult content and she was tasked with creating a new curriculum during a global trauma. She teaches well and cares. Figure it out.

The WORST prof ever! The positive reviews for her, she probably wrote herself from fake accounts. Material she teaches is completely unrelated to syllabus or to CS. Her 376W is mostly the same course as 105W because she doesn't know what to teach. Ignores students needs. I'm from Asia, had to stay up until 2am for mandatory attendance. SFU FIRE HER

I have learned many valuable research skills in this course, which can help me start my graduate study later this year. Although someone argues that the teaching materials are not CS-related, people should understand that this is a writing course. Writing is a transferrable skill. I recommend people who want to continue graduate study take this.

Jacquie's 376W is a complete waste of time! For a computer science technical writing course, course material and assignments certainly feel like an ESL class at times! Even though the course is a disgrace to the faculty and students, do yourself a favour and take this course with anyone other than Jacquie!

Want 11 quizzes in one day? Want 70 assignments/quizzes (not joking) by the end of the term including 2, 48-hour weekend group projects that are meaningless? Does not teach the curriculum stated in the outline. Often does not answer questions properly because she gets defensive and won't actually read what you're asking. Horrendous prof, avoid!!!

Extremely disorganized class, with material copy-pasted from CMPT 105W. Only half of the material that is copy-pasted is double-checked, so instructions become unclear, with conflicting word counts for the same assignment. If you miss the word count, you get 0. She says she doesn't scale. Uses TA's outside of the faculty.

CMPT376W was quite easy with Fred. He had some interesting stories from time to time and was very nice about mixups with submissions.

If you are going to take this class you should take it with him. It will be pretty easy and straight forward but if you're in CS you probably don't like writing courses anyways.
Fred's got a great sense of humour. Very easy marker. I'm a fob and still pulled an A. If English is your first language there's no reason why you cannot get an A+.
Fred is a great professor for this course. He was very clear and made this writing course somewhat enjoyable. Highly recommend for this course.
One of the best prof I have had from all the CMPT course I took in SFU. He explained the concepts well and was always prepared before class. Marking scheme is nice and easy.

He taught this course with Tara and seemed to defer all assignments to her. Given Tara's incompetence, this was a disaster. While the TAs are undoubtably smart people, it's bizarre to have people who speak English as a second language be the markers for an English writing course. Predictably, there were all sorts of erroneous marking decisions.

Workload was balanced, exam was really fair, responds to emails quickly, lectures are okay (could be more engaging and kind of just reads from slides), in-class activities for participation marks so you have to attend unless someone can get you the code for the day but really liked the course overall because John is super chill and friendly
He's a chill guy. Even a morning class never felt sleepy. Really help students.
